items.title: Definition of Simultaneous Equations
items.content_latex: The graph alongside shows the straight lines with equations $x + y = 4$ and $x - 2y = -2$. From the graph we can see the lines meet in exactly one point. This means there is exactly one solution for $x$ and $y$ which satisfies \textbf{both} equations. We have \textbf{two equations} involving the \textbf{two variables} $x$ and $y$. We say that $\begin{cases} x + y = 4 \\ x - 2y = -2 \end{cases}$ are \textbf{simultaneous equations}.

items.title: Method of Substitution
items.content_latex: The method of \textbf{solution by substitution} is used when at least one equation is given with either $x$ or $y$ as the \textbf{subject} of the formula. We substitute an expression for this variable into the other equation.

items.title: Example 1
items.content_latex:
Solve simultaneously by substitution: $y = x + 5$ and $3x - y = 1$.

$y = x + 5 \quad \ldots (1)$
$3x - y = 1 \quad \ldots (2)$

Since $y = x + 5$, $3x - (x + 5) = 1$
$\therefore 3x - x - 5 = 1$
$\therefore 2x = 6$
$\therefore x = 3$

When $x = 3$, $y = 3 + 5$ \{substituting $x = 3$ into (1)\}
$\therefore y = 8$

The solution is $x = 3$, $y = 8$.

\textit{Check:} (1) $8 = 3 + 5$ \checkmark
(2) $3(3) - 8 = 9 - 8 = 1$ \checkmark

items.title: Example 2
items.content_latex:
Solve simultaneously by substitution: $-2y + x = 5$ and $x = 7 + 3y$.

$-2y + x = 5 \quad \ldots (1)$
$x = 7 + 3y \quad \ldots (2)$

Substituting (2) into (1) gives
$-2y + (7 + 3y) = 5$
$\therefore -2y + 7 + 3y = 5$
$\therefore y + 7 = 5$
$\therefore y = -2$

Substituting $y = -2$ into (2) gives
$x = 7 + 3(-2) = 1$.

The solution is $x = 1$, $y = -2$.

\textit{Check:} (1) $-2(-2) + 1 = 4 + 1 = 5$ \checkmark
(2) $7 + 3(-2) = 7 - 6 = 1$ \checkmark

items.title: Exercise 14C
items.content_latex: Find the simultaneous solution of the following pairs of equations using an algebraic method:

questions.label: 3a
questions.problem_latex: Use substitution to find the point of intersection: $y = 2x + 3$ and $y = x + 5$

questions.label: 3b
questions.problem_latex: Use substitution to find the point of intersection: $y = x - 3$ and $y = 3x + 1$

questions.label: 3c
questions.problem_latex: Use substitution to find the point of intersection: $y = 2 - x$ and $2x + y = -1$

questions.label: 3d
questions.problem_latex: Use substitution to find the point of intersection: $y = 3x + 2$ and $3x + 7y = -10$

questions.label: 3e
questions.problem_latex: Use substitution to find the point of intersection: $y = 2x - 5$ and $3x + y = 7$

questions.label: 3f
questions.problem_latex: Use substitution to find the point of intersection: $4x + 7y = 10$ and $y = 5 - 3x$

items.title: Method of Elimination
items.content_latex:
In many problems which require the simultaneous solution of linear equations, each equation will be of the form $ax + by = c$. Solution by substitution is often tedious in such situations and the method of \textbf{elimination} of one of the variables is preferred.

In this method, we make the coefficients of $x$ (or $y$) the \textbf{same size} but \textbf{opposite in sign} and then \textbf{add} the equations. This has the effect of \textbf{eliminating} one of the variables.

The method of elimination uses the fact that: if $a = b$ and $c = d$ then $a + c = b + d$.

items.title: Example 3
items.content_latex:
Solve simultaneously, by elimination: $3x + 2y = 5 \ldots (1)$ and $x - 2y = 3 \ldots (2)$.

Notice that the coefficients of $y$ are the same size but opposite in sign.
We \textbf{add} the LHSs and the RHSs to get an equation which contains $x$ only.

$\begin{array}{rcl}
3x + 2y &=& 5 \\
+ \quad x - 2y &=& 3 \\
\hline
4x &=& 8 \quad \text{\{adding the equations\}} \\
\therefore x &=& 2 \quad \text{\{dividing both sides by 4\}}
\end{array}$

Substituting $x = 2$ into equation (1) gives
$3(2) + 2y = 5$
$\therefore 6 + 2y = 5$
$\therefore 2y = 5 - 6$ \{subtracting 6 from both sides\}
$\therefore 2y = -1$
$\therefore y = -\frac{1}{2}$ \{dividing both sides by 2\}

The solution is $x = 2$ and $y = -\frac{1}{2}$.

\textit{Check:} in (2): $(2) - 2(-\frac{1}{2}) = 2 + 1 = 3$ \checkmark

items.title: Example 4
items.content_latex:
Solve simultaneously, by elimination: $3x + 2y = 8$ and $2x - 3y = 1$.

$3x + 2y = 8 \quad \ldots (1)$
$2x - 3y = 1 \quad \ldots (2)$

We can eliminate $y$ by multiplying (1) by 3 and (2) by 2.

$\begin{array}{rcll}
9x + 6y &=& 24 & \{(1) \times 3\} \\
+ \quad 4x - 6y &=& 2 & \{(2) \times 2\} \\
\hline
13x &=& 26 & \text{\{adding the equations\}} \\
\therefore x &=& 2 & \text{\{dividing both sides by 13\}}
\end{array}$

Substituting $x = 2$ into equation (1) gives
$3(2) + 2y = 8$
$\therefore 6 + 2y = 8$
$\therefore 2y = 2$
$\therefore y = 1$

So, the solution is: $x = 2$, $y = 1$.

\textit{Check:} $3(2) + 2(1) = 6 + 2 = 8$ \checkmark
$2(2) - 3(1) = 4 - 3 = 1$ \checkmark

items.title: Practice Worksheet
items.content_latex: Solve all these equations on your own paper!

items.title: Example - Sum and Difference Problem
items.content_latex:
Two numbers have a sum of 30 and a difference of 5. Find the numbers.

Let $x$ and $y$ be the unknown numbers, with $x > y$.

So, $x + y = 30 \ldots (1)$ \{'sum' means add\}
and $x - y = 5 \ldots (2)$ \{'difference' means subtract\}

adding $2x = 35$
$\therefore x = 17\frac{1}{2}$

Substituting into (1), $17\frac{1}{2} + y = 30$
$\therefore y = 12\frac{1}{2}$

The numbers are $17\frac{1}{2}$ and $12\frac{1}{2}$.

\textit{Check:} $17\frac{1}{2} + 12\frac{1}{2} = 30$ \checkmark
$17\frac{1}{2} - 12\frac{1}{2} = 5$ \checkmark

items.title: Example 7 - Coin Problem
items.content_latex:
Colin has a jar containing only 5-cent and 20-cent coins. In total there are 31 coins with a total value of \$3.50. How many of each type of coin does Colin have?

Let $x$ be the number of 5-cent coins and $y$ be the number of 20-cent coins.

$\therefore x + y = 31 \ldots (1)$ \{the total number of coins\}
and $5x + 20y = 350 \ldots (2)$ \{the total value of coins\}

To eliminate $x$, we multiply (1) by $-5$.

$\therefore -5x - 5y = -155 \ldots (3)$
$5x + 20y = 350 \ldots (2)$
$\therefore 15y = 195$ \{adding (3) and (2)\}
$\therefore y = 13$ \{dividing both sides by 15\}

Substituting $y = 13$ into (1) gives $x + 13 = 31$
$\therefore x = 18$

\textit{Check:} $18 + 13 = 31$ \checkmark
$5 \times 18 + 20 \times 13 = 350$ \checkmark

Colin has 18 5-cent coins and 13 20-cent coins.

items.title: Example 8 - Boat Speed Problem
items.content_latex:
A boat travels 24 km upstream in 4 hours. The return trip downstream takes only 3 hours. The speed of the current is constant throughout the entire trip. Find:
a) the speed of the current
b) the speed of the boat in still water.

Let the speed of the boat in still water be $x$ km per hour, and the speed of the current be $y$ km per hour.

speed upstream $= \frac{24 \text{ km}}{4 \text{ h}} = 6 \text{ km h}^{-1}$
speed downstream $= \frac{24 \text{ km}}{3 \text{ h}} = 8 \text{ km h}^{-1}$

When the boat is travelling upstream,
boat speed $-$ current speed $=$ actual speed
$\therefore x - y = 6 \ldots (1)$

When the boat is travelling downstream,
boat speed $+$ current speed $=$ actual speed
$\therefore x + y = 8 \ldots (2)$

Adding (1) and (2), $2x = 14$
$\therefore x = 7$

Substituting $x = 7$ in (1), $7 - y = 6$
$\therefore y = 1$

\textit{Check:} $7 - 1 = 6$ \checkmark and $7 + 1 = 8$ \checkmark

a) The current speed is 1 km h$^{-1}$.
b) The boat speed in still water is 7 km h$^{-1}$.

items.title: Example 9 - Shopping Problem
items.content_latex:
At a clearance sale all CDs are sold for one price and all DVDs are sold for another price.
Marisa bought 3 CDs and 2 DVDs for a total of \$34.50, and Nico bought 2 CDs and 5 DVDs for a total of \$56.
Find the cost of each item.

Let $x$ cents be the cost of one CD and $y$ cents be the cost of one DVD.

3 CDs and 2 DVDs cost \$34.50, so $3x + 2y = 3450 \ldots (1)$
2 CDs and 5 DVDs cost \$56, so $2x + 5y = 5600 \ldots (2)$

We will eliminate $x$ by multiplying equation (1) by 2 and equation (2) by $-3$.

$\therefore 6x + 4y = 6900$
$-6x - 15y = -16800$

adding $-11y = -9900$
$\therefore y = 900$

Substituting in equation (1) gives $3x + 2 \times 900 = 3450$
$\therefore 3x + 1800 = 3450$
$\therefore 3x = 1650$
$\therefore x = 550$

So, the cost of one CD is \$5.50 and the cost of one DVD is \$9.

items.title: Example 10 - Furniture Problem
items.content_latex:
A carpenter makes cabinets and desks. Each cabinet has 2 doors and 3 drawers, and each desk has 1 door and 5 drawers, the same as are used for the cabinets. The carpenter has 41 doors and 100 drawers available. How many of each item of furniture should he make to use his entire supply of doors and drawers?

Suppose the carpenter makes $x$ cabinets and $y$ desks.

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|}
\hline
\textit{Item} & \textit{Number} & \textit{Doors} & \textit{Drawers} \\
\hline
Cabinet & $x$ & $2x$ & $3x$ \\
\hline
Desk & $y$ & $y$ & $5y$ \\
\hline
Total & & 41 & 100 \\
\hline
\end{tabular}

$\therefore 2x + y = 41 \ldots (1)$ \{total number of doors\}
$3x + 5y = 100 \ldots (2)$ \{total number of drawers\}

Multiplying (1) by $-5$ gives $-10x - 5y = -205$
$3x + 5y = 100$

adding $-7x = -105$
$\therefore x = 15$ \{dividing both sides by $-7$\}

Substituting $x = 15$ into (1) gives $2 \times 15 + y = 41$
$\therefore 30 + y = 41$
$\therefore y = 11$

So, the carpenter should make 15 cabinets and 11 desks.

items.title: Example 11 - Triangle Problem
items.content_latex:
An equilateral triangle has sides of length $(3x - y)$ cm, $(x + 5)$ cm and $(y + 3)$ cm. Find the length of each side.

The sides of an equilateral triangle are equal.
$\therefore 3x - y = y + 3$
$\therefore 3x - 2y = 3 \ldots (1)$ \{subtracting $y$ from both sides\}

Also $3x - y = x + 5$
$\therefore 2x - y = 5 \ldots (2)$ \{subtracting $x$ from both sides\}

$3x - 2y = 3$
Multiplying (2) by $-2$: $-4x + 2y = -10$

adding $-x = -7$
$\therefore x = 7$

Substituting in (1): $3(7) - 2y = 3$
$\therefore 21 - 2y = 3$
$\therefore -2y = -18$
$\therefore y = 9$

$3x - y = 21 - 9 = 12$, $x + 5 = 7 + 5 = 12$ and $y + 3 = 9 + 3 = 12$
$\therefore$ the sides are 12 cm long.

questions.problem_latex: Two numbers have a sum of 200 and a difference of 37. Find the numbers.
The difference between two numbers is 84 and their sum is 278. What are the numbers?
One number exceeds another by 11. The sum of the two numbers is 5. What are the numbers?
The larger of two numbers is four times the smaller and their sum is 85. Find the two numbers.
Find two integers such that three times the smaller is 33 more than twice the larger, and twice the smaller plus five times the larger equals 250.
Two hammers and a screwdriver cost a total of \$34. A hammer and 3 screwdrivers cost a total of \$32. Find the price of each type of tool.
Four adults and three children go to a theatre for \pounds74, whereas two adults and five children are charged \pounds58. Find the price of an adult's ticket and a child's ticket.
Three blankets and a sheet cost me RM190. Two sheets and a blanket cost a total of RM100. Find the cost of one blanket and one sheet.
Seven peaches plus eight nashi cost me \yen273 altogether. However, three peaches and one nashi cost a total of \yen66. Find the cost of one piece of each fruit.
A purse contains \$3.75 in 5 cent and 20 cent coins. If there are 33 coins altogether, how many of each type of coin are in the purse?
A yard contains rabbits and pheasants only. There are 35 heads and 98 feet in the yard. How many rabbits and pheasants does the yard contain?
Milk is sold in one litre and two litre cartons. A delicatessen owner orders 120 litres of milk and receives 97 cartons. How many of each type did she receive?
The figure alongside is a rectangle. Find $x$ and $y$. [Rectangle with sides $(3x-5)$ cm, $(2x-4)$ cm, $(y-3)$ cm, and $(y-1)$ cm]
KLM is an isosceles triangle. Find $x$ and $y$ and hence find the measure of the angle at K. [Triangle with angles $(x+4)^\circ$, $(y-9)^\circ$, and $(x+y+3)^\circ$]
Twelve years ago Jane was five times as old as Anne. In three years' time Anne will be half Jane's age. How old is each girl at the moment?
Nine years ago a woman was three times as old as her son. In eight years from now the sum of their ages will be 78. How old are they today?
The weekly wages of Sam and Ben are in the ratio of $2:1$. Their living costs are in the ratio of $9:4$. If each saves \$100 per week, find their weekly incomes.
The sum of two numbers is 47 and their difference is 14. Find the numbers.
Find two numbers whose difference is 3 and average is 5.
The larger of two numbers is four times the smaller, and their sum is 85. Find the two numbers.
At the local stationery shop, five pencils and six biros cost a total of \texteuro4.64, and seven pencils and three biros cost a total of \texteuro3.58. Find the cost of each item.
Seven toffees and three chocolates cost a total of \$1.68, whereas four toffees and five chocolates cost a total of \$1.65. Find the cost of each of the sweets.
I have only 50-cent and \$1 coins in my purse. There are 43 coins and their total value is \$35. How many of each coin type do I have?
Amy and Michelle have \texteuro29.40 between them. Amy's money totals three quarters of Michelle's. How much money does each have?
Margarine is sold in either 250 g or 400 g packs. A hotel ordered 19.6 kg of margarine and received 58 packs. How many of each type did the hotel receive?
Given that the triangle alongside is equilateral, find $a$ and $b$. [Triangle with sides $(b+2)$ cm, $(a+4)$ cm, and $(4a-b)$ cm]
A rectangle has perimeter 32 cm. If 3 cm is taken from the length and added to the width, the rectangle becomes a square. Find the dimensions of the original rectangle.
A motor boat travels at 12 km h$^{-1}$ upstream against the current and 18 km h$^{-1}$ downstream with the current. Find the speed of the current and the speed of the motor boat in still water.

A jet plane made a 4000 km trip downwind in 4 hours, but required 5 hours to make the return trip. Assuming the speed of the wind was constant throughout the entire journey, find the speed of the wind and the average speed of the plane in still air.

A man on foot covers the 25 km between two towns in $3\frac{3}{4}$ hours. He walks at 4 km h$^{-1}$ for the first part of the journey and runs at 12 km h$^{-1}$ for the remaining part.
a) How far did he run?
b) For how long was he running?

questions.label: 14a
questions.problem_latex: Explain why any two digit number can be written in the form $10a + b$.

questions.label: 14b
questions.problem_latex: A number consists of two digits which add up to 9. When the digits are reversed, the original number is decreased by 45. What was the original number?
